Situation1: They travel a long distance to participate in an important religious festival, ensuring they fully engage in all rituals and offerings.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Late-afternoon errands leave just a couple of hours before the polls close.
Story: I had been looking forward to the festival for weeks, the air thick with the scent of incense and marigolds as I joined my family at the temple. The rituals were long and meaningful, each chant and offering connecting me to my heritage. My relatives expected me to stay until the final aarti, to show respect and devotion. But as the sun dipped lower, I glanced at my watch and felt a knot tighten in my stomach. The polling station would close in just a couple of hours, and I still had errands to run before I could even think about heading there. My parents reminded me how important it was to honor our traditions, while my friends messaged me, urging me not to waste my vote. I felt torn, the weight of my community’s expectations pressing on one side, and my sense of civic duty on the other. The temple bells rang louder, but so did the ticking clock in my mind. I stood at the threshold, heart pounding, unsure which path to take.
